title: Neuropathic Pain Management
scope: ** Treatment-focused plan for neuropathic pain management in adults. Covers peripheral neuropathic pain (diabetic, post-herpetic, traumatic, chemotherapy-induced) and central neuropathic pain (post-stroke, spinal cord injury, MS-related). Includes pain screening tools (DN4, LANSS), step therapy per AAN/EFNS/NeuPSIG guidelines, combination therapy strategies, opioid risk assessment, interventional options, and deprescribing guidance. Covers ED acute exacerbation, inpatient management, and outpatient chronic care. Excludes diagnostic workup for neuropathy etiology (covered in neuropathy-specific plans).

Patient Instructions.rationale: Tracks treatment response; identifies patterns; guides medication adjustment

Patient Instructions.item: Set realistic expectations: goal is >=30% pain reduction and improved function, not zero pain
Patient Instructions.rationale: Prevents treatment frustration; aligns goals with achievable outcomes

Patient Instructions.item: Medication adherence: take scheduled medications regularly even when pain is low
Patient Instructions.rationale: Preventive effect requires steady-state levels; PRN use alone is less effective

Patient Instructions.item: Do not abruptly stop gabapentinoids, SNRIs, or TCAs (taper required)
Patient Instructions.rationale: Withdrawal seizures (gabapentinoids); discontinuation syndrome (SNRIs); cardiac risk (TCAs)

Patient Instructions.item: Opioid safety counseling: store securely, no sharing, disposal of unused medication, naloxone training
Patient Instructions.rationale: Prevent diversion, accidental ingestion, overdose death; mandatory for opioid prescriptions

Patient Instructions.item: Naloxone (Narcan) co-prescription: obtain and keep accessible if receiving any opioid
Patient Instructions.rationale: Reverses opioid overdose; FDA recommends co-prescribing with all opioid prescriptions

Patient Instructions.item: Avoid alcohol and sedatives with CNS-depressant medications
Patient Instructions.rationale: Additive CNS depression with gabapentinoids, opioids, TCAs; respiratory depression risk

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED for sudden severe pain escalation, new weakness, bowel/bladder dysfunction
Patient Instructions.rationale: May indicate new neurologic emergency (cord compression, cauda equina)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (walking, swimming, cycling) 30 min x 5 days/week
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Level A evidence for pain reduction; improves endogenous pain modulation; reduces comorbid depression

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for chronic pain
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Level A evidence as adjunct; reduces pain catastrophizing; improves coping and function
Poor sleep amplifies pain perception; sleep disorders common in chronic pain; may reduce medication needs
Prevents neuropathy progression; HbA1c <7% associated with reduced pain severity
Smoking worsens neuropathy and pain perception; impairs microvascular circulation
Reduces mechanical nerve compression; improves metabolic syndrome; enhances mobility
Moderate evidence for chronic pain; reduces pain unpleasantness; complements pharmacotherapy

Deprescribing Guidance.item: Ineffective medication (no response after adequate trial at therapeutic dose)
Deprescribing Guidance.strategy: Taper and discontinue; document lack of efficacy
Deprescribing Guidance.timeline: Gabapentinoids: taper over 1-2 weeks; SNRIs: taper over 2-4 weeks; TCAs: taper over 2-4 weeks

Deprescribing Guidance.item: Opioid reduction for stable chronic neuropathic pain
Deprescribing Guidance.strategy: Optimize non-opioid regimen first; reduce opioid by 10% of total daily dose q2-4 weeks
Deprescribing Guidance.timeline: 10% reduction q2-4 weeks; slower if withdrawal symptoms; pause taper if pain significantly worsens

Deprescribing Guidance.item: Opioid rotation (inadequate relief or intolerable side effects)
Deprescribing Guidance.strategy: Calculate morphine milligram equivalents (MME); convert at 50-75% of equianalgesic dose; cross-tolerance incomplete
Deprescribing Guidance.timeline: Complete transition over 3-7 days; close monitoring during rotation

Deprescribing Guidance.strategy: Eliminate least effective agent first; maintain agents with dual benefit (e.g., SNRI for pain + depression)
Deprescribing Guidance.timeline: One change at a time; reassess in 2-4 weeks before next change
